subject: Add initial support for polarity on a couple of GPIOs

Change-Id: If752506a16ca4091a8e68a3455850705a4ab8cd2

Patch Set 11:

I have updated the code to support as an input to polarity ActiveHigh or ActiveLow. This is then translated to a boolean value inside the code, and if it is not present it reports a failure. I have also updated the default json file to follow original design format, Hope this is answering to all the open questions we might have ;)

Patch Set 15: Code-Review+1

I kind of like the idea of adding a helper function to assert a GPIO based on polarity, but we can add that as a separate commit.  This looks good to me and works on my system.

I'll leave some time for others to provide any additional feedback before moving to +2.

I see some clean-ups/improvements that could be done for clarity regarding variable names and enumerations (as I've mentioned in earlier patch sets), but those could be done in a follow up commit.  Functionally it seems to work and it isn't especially terrible.

Look like we are converging. I might be looking at making the logic more modular, as we still need to fix the power sequencing for ProLiant
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 50937e7339db744f765efdc3cc58f3d0c5976601 by Jean-Marie Verdun
Looks like your vim swap file got 'git add'ed somehow.
Can this just be a boolean?  Or are you really trying to tri-state this?  If you want a tri-state, please define an enumeration.
I don't think a multi-line string is really what you intended.
Tabs left in here somehow.
This changes the polarity for the current source.
Ack

Do we need to handle the case where "Polarity" doesn't exist in the config file?  Can we just make it a required parameter and error out if it doesn't exist?  Then we don't have to handle the -1 case and can just directly use the polarity setting.

We could, but I am always gentle on modifying configuration file. Roughly we can offer either a smooth transition or a hard stop. Up to use to decide. I am more on the smooth transition side, but I am ok, with the hard stop.

We just added some other big changes to the config file, so I don't think anyone should have issue with additional changes.  As long as we set the config file with the existing polarity defaults, I think we can go with a hard stop to keep the code simpler.
ok then let me do that.

To be honest, this logic is confusing to me, but if Jason is fine with it so be it.

I would have expected that the presence of ConfigData implied that that ConfigData *had* the polarity, not that the ConfigData ends up inverting the default polarity.  The way this logic is specifying, it means that someone has to know the "default" polarity for each pin in order to reverse engineer the desired value for their machine.

The challenge here is that, for each pin we have to define if it is active low or active high. This is what the polarity parameter remember. Then we have transient state which are driven by GPIO value, and drive a flip/flop approach, which explain the logic. I am not a big fan of it, but by pushing it here, it is lowering code modifications.

Hmm... These are good points.  We only use setGPIOOutputForMs() in a few places and it is always to assert the GPIO.  If it would be cleaner, I'd be okay changing it to something like assertGPIOforMs() and then use the polarity to assert the GPIO instead of taking the value as a parameter.
`const std::string& name = config.lineName`?
Looks like this function needs to be updated like the powerOut functions above.
Can this message be one line to avoid the '\' and tabs?
There is an update to our global .clang-format which should probably be replicated to this repository.  It adds "BreakStringLiterals: false" which allows long strings.

If "Polarity" can still be an int, should this be treated as 0 is false and all other values are true?

So, would this work
tempGpioData->polarity = (temp != 0)
OpenBMC style is to use curly braces even on single-line if-else statements.
I'm surprised the .clang-format doesn't enforce this.  Maybe only clang-tidy does.
Same here?
Do we really want to pass the `ConfigData` struct by value here?  I'd have expected a const reference or the like.
I can put a const reference, and will do it tomorrow.

Did it not work as a reference?

I'd expect it to build with "const ConfigData& config".
Just updated it.

I may be mistaken (I'm not a C++ guru), but I think as-is this will lead to undefined behavior by dereferencing a dangling reference, because this function (with a local copy of `config`) returns, leaving the callback function in the `.async_wait()` with a stale `name` reference.  (Changing the `config` parameter to a reference as suggested above should fix it though, I think.)

Depending on the compiler the unnamed function definition for the async_wait call will capture the reference and create a copy of the required values as long as they are locally declared. So the name shall be ok, but I might be wrong.

Perhaps I'm misunderstanding what's going on here, but does this imply we're going to have config bits like `"Polarity": "1"`, with a string value for the key, instead of `"Polarity": 1` with a numeric value?  If so, I'm a bit confused as to why...

I'm somewhat tempted to suggest having this config item be a json bool ("ActiveLow" or something) so as to avoid the question of what meaning to assign integer values other than zero and one, though I guess that might be a bit more invasive to apply back to all the existing signals...

I try to keep it simple. Everything was declared as string into the json, so I kept a string approach avoiding the frustrating error of the double quote vs none when declaring an integer. I made the conversion into the c++ code as you observed it. I am ok to put a bool value directly into json, but I think only true and false are normalized (not 0 or 1)

If we are going to use the polarity to drive the GPIO, it may be safer to make it mandatory in the config file like the "LineName" above and return an error here instead of defaulting to false.  But I'm okay either way since this maintains the current default setting.
Look like everybody wants it. So let's do it. We could also have done it in a step by step manner.
ActiveLow?
Done
The current default for NMI_OUT looks like it is ActiveHigh.
Done
For these GPIOs from line 21 that are set to ActiveHigh, it looks like the current default is ActiveLow for all of them except PS_PWROK and SIO_POWER_GOOD.
Done in latest patch set

Thanks. This polarity field helps other x86-platforms to adapt x86-power-control.
Also, other x86-platforms does not have all the states that Intel platforms has. Can the state machine be made configurable as well?

> Can the state machine be made configurable as well?

I'll let Jason answer this but I expect he will say "of course, if someone wants to contribute the code".  I don't think this is a feature that Jason or JM are planning to contribute at this time, so if it is necessary for AMD systems, you probably should build that support on top of what JM has done here.

Yep.  I agree with Patrick.  I have thought about how to make it more flexible and configurable but only at a very high level.  I had some vague thoughts of making each state a separate object that could be optionally included and customized with its response to the various events.  But I didn't have any good ideas on how to implement that (or even if it's a good approach).
Done

Was there anything that needed to be adjusted with this logic now that the config is "ActiveHigh"/"ActiveLow"?  As I remarked in PS6, I still find this logic non-obvious.

Maybe the 'obviousness' solution is to switch 'value' to be a boolean named "active"?
Yes, I think this can be clarified a bit.  I had an idea to make an assertGPIOForMs() helper function that would derive the assert value from the polarity.  I can push it as a separate patch.
Done
